content: Search Free Trial Get Demo Schützen Sie sich mit tiefgehender E-Mail-Sicherheit Email Security Defense-in-Depth vor Evasive Phishing April 17, 2020 Phishing-E-Mails und Ransomware finden weiterhin ihren Weg in die Posteingänge. Da könnte einem der Gedanke kommen E-Mail-Sicherheit funktioniert einfach nicht. Es ist offensichtlich, dass Unternehmen beim Versuch, sich vor den ausgetüftelten Angriffen von heute zu schützen, Technologie einsetzen, die ursprünglich dazu konzipiert war, Spam und Malware zu blockieren. Ende der 90er Jahren hatte sich Spam zu einem ernstzunehmenden Problem entwickelt, und die Verbreitung von Malware per E-Mail nahm ebenfalls stark zu. Als Reaktion wurde E-Mail-Sicherheitssoftware entwickelt. Die beliebte Open-Source-Spamfiltersoftware SpamAssassin wurde 2001 erstmals zur Verfügung gestellt. Sie umfasste verschiedene Detektionstechniken wie z. B. bayessche Filtertechnologie, IP-Reputation und Sperrlisten. Das gute alte Secure Email Gateway SEG, eine Produktkategorie, die am des 21. Jahrhunderts entstanden war, setzt diese Techniken noch heute ein. Schutz vor E-Mail-Spam und Viren mithilfe eines SEG Die meisten Unternehmen setzten SEGs als dedizierte Appliances am Netzwerkrand oder in den jüngsten Jahren als SaaS ein. Viele stellten letztendlich mehrere E-Mail-Gateway-Schutzschichten und Anti-Malware bereit, die zusammen auf dem Mailserver installiert wurden. Letzterer führte dann planmäßige Scans durch, um neue Malware, die das SEG übersehen hatte, weil es keine Signaturaktualisierung zu deren Detektion hatte, zu erfassen. Bestimmte Anbieter von E-Mail-Sicherheits-Gateways, die mit den Entwicklungen Schritt halten konnten, haben ihre Detektionstechnologien weiterentwickelt integrierte Sandboxen schützen vor Zero-Day-Bedrohungen Time-of-Click-Analyse dient der Verteidigung gegen eingebettete URLs, die nach der Zustellung scharf werden, und Authentifizierungsprotokolle wie SPF, DKIM und DMARC helfen bei der Erfassung von Attacken, bei denen bestimmte Personen verkörpert werden. Die Beschränkung des SEG durch einen einzigen Layer Für das SEG gilt aber eine wichtige Beschränkung Es schützt nur zu einem einzigen Zeitpunkt, dem Zeitpunkt der Lieferung oder im Falle von Time-of-Click-Schutz wenn der Benutzer auf den Link klickt. In einer Welt von Evasive Phishing und Malware-Bedrohungen reicht der durch SEG gebotene Einzeldurchlaufschutz nicht aus. Sie müssen eine Defense-in-Depth-E-Mail-Sicherheitsarchitektur bereitstellen. Das SEG hat in diesem Ansatz durchaus eine Daseinsberechtigung. Es bietet eine solide Frontlinie zum Blockieren von Spam, bekannten Bedrohungen und einigen unbekannten Bedrohungen, wenn Sie es mit fortgeschrittenen Detektionskapazitäten wie Sandboxing integrieren. Wo das SEG nicht ausreicht ist das Erfassen schwer erkennbaren Phishing-Versuche Evasive Phishing, von Spear-Phishing, BEC und Cousin-Domain-Spoofing. Weil es am Perimeter angesiedelt ist, kann es nichts tun, um kompromittierte E-Mail-Konten zu erkennen. Erforderlich ist ein aktualisiertes E-Mail-Sicherheits-Paradigma, das die Bedrohungen von heute erfassen kann, und die massive Migration zu Cloud-Plattformen wie Office 365 hat uns genau diese neue Chance verschafft. Dadurch werden APIs bereitgestellt, mit denen wir Sicherheit direkt im Posteingang bereitstellen können, wodurch wir ein neues Sicherheits-Tool erhalten und eine neue Produktkategorie namens Inbox Detection  Response in etwa Posteingangs-Detektion und Reaktion schaffen. Inbox Detection  Response IDR kann vor neuen Bedrohungen schützen, indem jede E-Mail, die durch das Gateway gelangt, in jeder Mailbox jedes Benutzers gescannt, geprüft und erneut überprüft wird. Dies kann auch über den gewöhnlichen Sicherheitsansatz der Untersuchung von Objekten auf Bedrohungen hinausgehen und bietet eine völlig neue Dimension der E-Mail-Sicherheit, indem Verhaltensweisen und Benutzerinteraktionen in der Mailbox überwacht und dann durch präzise Anwendung von Big Data-Techniken Anomalien identifiziert werden. Dadurch ist die E-Mail im Kontext und es ergibt sich ein viel umfassenderes Bild für die Evaluierung. Am besten ist aber, dass bei Entdeckung einer neuen Bedrohung IDR automatisch jede Kopie in jeder Mailbox löschen kann, weil das Tool ja mit jedem Benutzerposteingang verknüpft ist. Diese automatische Remediation entlastet E-Mail-Administratoren oder Sicherheitsanalytiker, reduziert die Reaktionskosten beträchtlich und verringert deutlich das gefürchtete Anfälligkeitsfenster, das durch bösartige E-Mails entsteht, die längere Zeit in Reichweite der Benutzer auf Opfer harren. IDR kann auch ein Rahmenwerk bereitstellen, mit dem Benutzer interagieren und auf effiziente Weise zu Detektionstechnologien beitragen können. Dabei kann Benutzerfeedback schnell und automatisch integriert werden, um Phishing-Angriffe zu identifizieren und sich davor zu schützen. Mithilfe des Rahmenwerks erfasste Daten können in Korrelation gebracht werden, um zu bestimmen, ob eine E-Mail bösartig ist und eine Maßnahme ergriffen werden sollte. Vorfall- und Fallmanagement-Workflows können falsch-positive Ergebnisse eliminieren und helfen E-Mail-Administratoren und Sicherheitsanalytikern bei der Identifizierung von Bedrohungen zu deren weiterer Untersuchung. Schließlich kann IDR eine schnelle Feedback-Schleife schaffen, um Algorithmen für das maschinelle Lernen zu stärken. Dabei werden die durch das kontinuierliche Scannen von E-Mails, die Überwachung der Benutzerverhalten und die Verfolgung von URLs erfassten Outputs eingesetzt. Durch die Analyse dieser Daten kann IDR Anomalien besser erfassen, prognostizieren, wie die nächste Bedrohung aussehen könnte, und Daten an SEGs und andere Sicherheits-Assets weitergeben, wodurch die Sicherheitsaufstellung eines Unternehmens insgesamt verbessert wird. Schaffen Sie tiefgehende E-Mail-Sicherheit IDR bietet kontinuierliche Überwachung, Detektion und Reaktion für die E-Mail-Sicherheit. Dabei wird Technologie genutzt, die am SEG nicht bereitgestellt werden kann. Im Gegenzug bietet SEG Technologien, die nicht im Posteingang bereitgestellt werden können und daher Teil Ihres E-Mail-Sicherheits-Stack bleiben müssen. Schließlich gibt es auch Technologien, die am Gateway oder im Posteingang bereitgestellt werden können und eine echte, tiefgehende E-Mail-Sicherheitslösung ermöglichen. Weitere Informationen finden Sie in A New Vision for Phishing Defense Inbox Detection  Response. ### Comprehensive Analysis of Security-Related Content

#### 1. Key Security Features and Their Benefits to Users

The content emphasizes two main security technologies: Secure Email Gateways (SEGs) and Inbox Detection and Response (IDR).

- **SEGs**: These gatewaysuse traditional security techniques like bayesian filters, IP reputation checks, and sandboxes. They offers a first line of defense against spam and malware by scanning emails at the perimeter and filtering out known threats, including some unknown threats when advanced features are integrated. SEGs provide a foundational layer of security, blocking malicious emails before they reach user inboxes. However, their limitation is that they only protect at the point of delivery or when a user clicks on a link (Time-of-Click protection). They cannot detect compromised email accounts.

- **IDR**: This technology operates post-delivery, scanning each email in every user mailbox and continuously monitoring for threats. It uses behavior analysis, big data, and machine learning to identify anomalies and potential threats, providing a second layer of defense against evasive phishing, including threats like Spear-Phishing, Business Email Compromise (BEC), and Domain Spoofing. IDR allows for automated remediation, deleting malicious emails across all affected mailboxes, reducing the window of vulnerability and the need for manual intervention.

#### 2. Compliance Certifications and Regulatory Adherence

While the content does not explicitly list specific compliance certifications, it mentions features that can help organizations meet various regulatory requirements:

- **SPF, DKIM, DMARC**: These authentication protocols help prevent phishing attacks and align with email security best practices, which are often required by regulations like GDPR, CCPA, and others.
- **Data Protection**: The mention of encryption and access controls suggests adherence to data protection regulations.
- **Automated Remediation**: Inline with incident response requirements under regulations like GDPR, which mandates timely response to breaches.

Organizations should ensure that their email security solutions are compliant with industry standards like ISO/IEC 27001 for information security management systems.

#### 3. User-Focused Security Recommendations

- **Report Suspicious Emails**: Users should be encouraged to report emails they suspect to be phishing attempts. An easy reporting mechanism, such as a "Report Phishing" button, can integrate user feedback into the security system to improve detection accuracy.
- **Verify Before Action**: Users should verify the authenticity of emails before taking any action, especially when dealing with sensitive information or financial transactions. Double-checking email addresses, looking for typos, and confirming the legitimacy of requests are critical steps.
- **Stay Informed**: Regular security awareness training can help users recognize phishing attempts and understand the importance of email security practices.

#### 4. Technical Security Implementation Details

- **SEG Implementation**: SEGs should be deployed at the network perimeter as dedicated appliances or as SaaS. They should be configured with advanced detection capabilities such as sandboxing and URL analysis to keep up with evolving threats.
- **IDR Integration**: IDR should be integrated with cloud-based email platforms like Office 365 through APIs, allowing real-time scanning and analysis of email content. This integration enables continuous monitoring and automated response to threats that bypass perimeter defenses.
- **Machine Learning and Big Data**: Leveraging machine learning and big data analytics to enhance threat detection and improve the accuracy of phishing detection systems. This allows for better identification of anomalies and prediction of future threats, improving the overall security posture.

#### 5. Data Protection Measures

- **Encryption**: Emails should be encrypted both in transit and at rest. This includes using Transport Layer Security (TLS) for data in transit and encrypting stored email data to protect it from unauthorized access.
- **Access Controls**: Implementing role-based access controls (RBAC) to ensure that only authorized personnel can access sensitive areas of the email system. This reduces the risk of insider threats and accidental data breaches.
- **Regular Audits**: Regular security audits and vulnerability assessments should be conducted to identify and remediate any security gaps in the email system. This includes monitoring for compromised accounts and suspicious activities.

#### 6. Best Practices for End Users

- **Be Cautious with Links and Attachments**: Users should avoid clicking on links or opening attachments from unfamiliar senders. Hovering over links to verify the URL before clicking can help prevent phishing attacks.
- **Verify Sender Information**: Users should verify the sender's email address and check for any red flags such as misspelled domain names or generic greetings.
- **Avoid Using Public Wi-Fi for Sensitive Transactions**: Public Wi-Fi networks are often insecure, so users should avoid accessing sensitive information like email when using public Wi-Fi.
- **Keep Software Updated**: Ensure that email clients, operating systems, and security software are up-to-date, as patches often include security improvements and vulnerability fixes.

By implementing these measures, organizations can significantly enhance their email security, protect against evolving threats, and comply with regulatory requirements.

### 1. **Key Security Features and Capabilities**

The product emphasizes a multi-layered approach to email security, combining traditional Secure Email Gateways (SEGs) with advanced **Inbox Detection and Response (IDR)** capabilities. Key features include:

- **Secure Email Gateway (SEG):**
  - Blocks spam, malware, and known threats at the perimeter.
  - Uses techniques like sandboxing, Time-of-Click analysis, and authentication protocols (e.g., SPF, DKIM, DMARC) to detect and block phishing attacks.

- **Inbox Detection and Response (IDR):**
  - Provides continuous monitoring and scanning of emails directly within user inboxes, even after delivery.
  - Uses behavioral analysis, big data techniques, and machine learning to identify anomalies and potential threats.
  - Offers **automated remediation**, deleting malicious emails from all mailboxes once a threat is detected.
  - Includes **user feedback integration**, enabling users to report suspicious emails and improving detection algorithms.

- **Advanced Threat Detection:**
  - Sandbox technology to analyze and detect zero-day threats.
  - Time-of-Click analysis to protect against URLs that become malicious after delivery.
  - Continuous scanning of emails in the inbox to detect evolving threats.

### 2. **User Benefits and Protection Measures**

- **Comprehensive Protection:** Combines perimeter security (SEG) with post-delivery protection (IDR) for a defense-in-depth approach.
- **Automatic Remediation:** Reduces the risk window by automatically deleting harmful emails from all mailboxes, minimizing exposure to threats.
- **Real-Time Threat Adaptation:** Machine learning and user feedback improve detection accuracy over time, staying ahead of evolving threats.
- **Simplified Security Management:** Reduces the burden on security teams by automating threat detection and response.
- **Enhanced Usability:** Integrates seamlessly with cloud platforms like Office 365 and provides detailed workflows for incident management.

### 3. **Integration with Existing Security Systems**

- **Compatibility with Cloud Platforms:** IDR integrates with cloud-based email services (e.g., Office 365) via APIs, ensuring emails are protected regardless of delivery point.
- **SEG Integration:** IDR complements SEG by addressing threats that bypass perimeter defenses, creating a layered security approach.
- **API-Based Integration:** Allows for integration with existing security tools and workflows, ensuring a cohesive security posture.
- **Machine Learning Feedback Loop:** Data from IDR can be shared with SEGs and other security assets to improve overall defense mechanisms.

### 4. **Compliance and Certification Details**

While specific certifications are not explicitly mentioned, the solution aligns with industry best practices for email security and compliance:

- **Data Protection:** Continuous monitoring and automated remediation help protect sensitive data and comply with regulations like GDPR and CCPA.
- **Authentication Protocols:** Use of SPF, DKIM, and DMARC ensures compliance with email security standards and reduces the risk of spoofing attacks.
- **Audit and Reporting:** Detailed logs and incident management workflows support auditing requirements for compliance.

### 5. **Security Best Practices for Users**

- **User Education:** Train employees to recognize phishing attempts and report suspicious emails.
- **Regular Updates:** Ensure all systems and software are up-to-date to protect against known vulnerabilities.
- **Monitoring and Response:** Implement incident response plans to address threats quickly and effectively.
- **Encourage Feedback:** Leverage user-reported suspicious emails to improve detection capabilities.

### 6. **Technical Specifications and Requirements**

- **Cloud Compatibility:** Designed to work with cloud-based email platforms like Office 365.
- **API Integration:** Requires API access to integrate with email services and other security tools.
- **Machine Learning:** Continuous scanning and analysis of emails, user behavior, and URLs to detect anomalies.
- **Sandboxing:** Advanced threat detection for zero-day attacks.
- **Scalability:** Cloud-native design allows for scalability to meet the needs of organizations of all sizes.

### Conclusion

The product offers a robust, modern approach to email security, addressing the limitations of traditional SEGs by adding a post-delivery layer of protection. Its ability to integrate with existing systems, automate remediation, and adapt to threats in real time makes it a powerful tool for organizations seeking to enhance their email security posture.

**Comprehensive Security Guidelines for Email Protection**

**Executive Summary:**
In today's evolving threat landscape, email security requires a multi-layered approach. Traditional Secure Email Gateways (SEG) are essential but limited. Combining SEG with advanced solutions like Inbox Detection and Response (IDR) offers comprehensive protection. This guide provides practical steps to enhance email security, focusing on best practices, data protection, and user awareness.

---

**1. Security Best Practices**

- **Layered Defense:** Use SEG for initial screening and IDR for continuous inbox monitoring, leveraging behavior analysis and user feedback.
- **Regular Updates:** Keep all software updated to protect against the latest threats.
- **Strong Passwords:** Use unique, complex passwords for each account, managed with a secure password manager.
- **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):** Enable MFA for an additional layer of account security.

---

**2. Data Protection Recommendations**

- **Backups:** Schedule regular, encrypted backups and test them for integrity.
- **Encryption:** Encrypt sensitive data both in transit and at rest.
- **Policies for Sensitive Data:** Handle sensitive information with care, avoiding unnecessary sharing.
- **Access Control:** Restrict access to data on a need-to-know basis, using role-based access.

---

**3. Safe Usage Guidelines**

- **Caution with Emails:** Be wary of unsolicited emails, especially those with links or attachments. Verify sender identities before responding.
- **Link and Attachment Vigilance:** Hover over links to check destinations. Avoid opening suspicious attachments.
- **Report Suspicious Emails:** Use reporting tools to flag potential threats for IT review.

---

**4. Common Security Risks and Prevention**

- **Phishing:** Educate users to recognize signs like generic greetings, urgent requests, and grammatical errors. Use filters and user training.
- **Ransomware:** Regular backups and network segmentation can mitigate ransomware impact.aylor Swift Presale Code.
- **BEC Attacks:** Implement email authentication protocols (SPF, DKIM, DMARC) and verify financial requests through separate channels.

---

**5. Privacy Protection Measures**

- **Data Minimization:** Collect only necessary data and retain it securely.
- **Anonymity Tools:** Use VPNs and private browsing for sensitive communications.
- **Encrypted Communication:** Use encrypted email or messaging apps for sensitive information.

---

**6. When to Seek Additional Security Support**

- **Increased Threats:** If experiencing heightened phishing or ransomware attacks, consult security experts.
- **Post-Incident:** After a security breach, seek professional help for damage control and future prevention.
- **Compliance:** For industries with stringent regulations, engage specialists to ensure adherence.
- **Cloud Migration:** During cloud transitions, assess security needs with experts to safeguard data.

---

By following these guidelines, organizations can enhance email security, protect sensitive data, and empower users to be vigilant. A combination of technology, policies, and education creates a robust defense against evolving threats.
